newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: DENMARK SET TO HOLD REFERENDUM AGAIN ON EU TREATY.
newsitem.headline: DENMARK SET TO HOLD REFERENDUM AGAIN ON EU TREATY.

text.p: Denmark, whose voters initially rejected the Maastricht treaty in 1992, must almost certainly hold a new referendum on the outcome of EU reform talks, Economy Minister Marianne Jelved said on Monday.

Jelved, participating at the two-day summit of European Union leaders in Amsterdam which is due to conclude negotiations on a revised EU treaty, said it was a "99 percent" probability that Denmark would need to hold such a public vote.
"But we have to wait to see the final text," she told Reuters, referring to the treaty text which is being negotiated by EU leaders.
Jelved added that such a referendum could be held in February or March next year.

Denmark, traditionally cool towards closer EU integration, threw the 15-nation bloc into chaos and confusion five years ago when its voters rejected the Maastricht treaty, which was agreed in the Dutch town of the same name in 1991.
The Danes accepted the treaty in a new vote the following year, but only after their government negotiated opt-outs from some of its key aims, including economic and monetary union (EMU).
The revised treaty expected to be agreed in Amsterdam is seen as much less far-reaching than the Maastricht treaty, which laid down the path towards EMU.
It is intended to help pave the way for eastern enlargement of the bloc, a key Danish priority, and also aims to create an area of "freedom, security and justice" in Europe.

Asked whether the likely outcome of the negotiations in Amsterdam would be so far-reaching that it would be hard to win the approval of the Danes, Jelved said: "It is difficult to answer...we need a debate after the final text."
She stressed that a majority of the Danish people wanted the EU reform talks to facilitate enlargement, indicating this could be a factor in determining their views.
Danish Prime Minister Poul Nyrup Rasmussen has repeatedly said Denmark's opt-outs would not be affected by the revised treaty.
But because of them, the country may have problems with proposals on common EU visa, immigration and asylum policies, EU diplomats say.

Further underlining the eurosceptical attitudes of many Danes, a Danish court started a hearing last month on a challenge to the legality of Denmark's EU treaties which legal experts say could end the country's EU membership under the present terms. A definitive verdict may not come until the end of 1997 or later.

The plaintiffs, a non-partisan group of 10 Danes, argue that since joining the EU in 1973, Denmark has ceded national authority to EU institutions in breach of its own constitution. But the centre-left coalition government believes its case is watertight.
